questions.text: A 71-year-old man with hypertension and hyperlipidemia is brought to the emergency department after the sudden onset of slurred speech 1 hour ago. Physical examination shows drooling and hypernasal speech. His face is symmetric and strength is 5/5 in all extremities. This patient's presentation is most consistent with injury to which of the labeled areas of the primary motor cortex?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This area of the motor homunculus corresponds with the motor innervation of the muscles of the throat involved in swallowing, as well as the tongue, mastication, and vocalization. Slurred speech and drooling are signs of injury to this area, most likely due to an ischemic stroke.
Image Description:

The motor homunculus is a map of the primary motor cortex (located in the precentral gyrus of the frontal lobes) that illustrates which areas of the brain process the motor output to which part of the body. The distorted representation of the body and the size of the correspondingly labeled cortical areas illustrate the proportional amount of motor output sent to the individual parts of the body. Accordingly, since areas like the tongue, face, and hands receive most motor innervation, these areas are represented as disproportionately large compared to other areas, like the trunk and lower limbs.

B) INCORRECT:

This corresponds to the region of the motor homunculus that is responsible for facial expressions. This patient's face is symmetric, and his drooling and hypernasal speech suggest the involvement of a different labeled area.

C) INCORRECT:

This corresponds to the region of the motor homunculus that is responsible for the movement of the index finger. This patient does not present with impaired index finger function.

D) INCORRECT:

This corresponds to the region of the motor homunculus that is responsible for the movement of the wrist. This patient does not present with impaired wrist flexion/extension or adduction/abduction

E) INCORRECT:

This corresponds to the region of the motor homunculus that is responsible for the movement of the toe. This patient does not present with toe or foot paralysis.
questions.hint: This patient presents with signs of an ischemic stroke. His slurred speech and drooling indicate pathological changes in the cortical area responsible for the central control of swallowing and vocalization. The motor homunculus represents all parts of the body arranged medially to laterally.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man with hypertension and congenital blindness comes to the physician because he is unable to recognize objects by touch with his right hand. The symptoms started about 2 hours ago. When given a house key, he can feel the object in his right hand but is not able to identify what it is. This patient's condition is most likely caused by a lesion in which of the following locations?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The inferior frontal gyrus of the dominant hemisphere encompasses the Broca area, which is involved in speech production. A lesion in the Broca area causes expressive aphasia, not astereognosis.

B) INCORRECT:

The superior temporal gyrus consists of the primary auditory cortex and auditory association cortex, which is part of Wernicke area in the dominant hemisphere. A lesion in this area causes slight loss of hearing, difficulty of sound localization, and Wernicke aphasia if the dominant hemisphere is involved.

C) CORRECT:

The somatosensory association cortex is located in the superior parietal lobule and is involved in tactile information processing and spatial orientation. A lesion in the left superior parietal lobule can cause contralateral (i.e. right-sided in this case) astereognosis. Hemispatial neglect can also result from parietal lobe damage; however, it is more characteristic of right parietal lobe lesions, rather than the left parietal lobe lesion seen here.

D) INCORRECT:

The precentral gyrus is the location of the primary motor cortex, which controls the motor function of the contralateral body. A lesion in this area leads to contralateral spastic paralysis, not astereognosis.

E) INCORRECT:

The cingulate gyrus is part of the limbic system, which is involved in emotion, feeding, mating, learning, and memory formation. Decreased volume of the anterior cingulate gyrus has been associated with a lowered level of social functioning in patients with schizophrenia. A cingulate gyrus lesion does not cause astereognosis.
questions.hint: The ability to recognize objects by touch is called stereognosis. Tactile information is processed by the secondary somatosensory cortex (somatosensory association cortex).

questions.text: A 55-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of sudden-onset of difficulty speaking for 1 hour. He has hypertension, dyslipidemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include atorvastatin, lisinopril, and metformin. He is 213 cm (7 ft) tall. On examination, the patient speaks slowly in simple sentences that consist of only one word. He seems to have difficulties understanding grammatically complex sentences and appears to be frustrated at the inability to speak fluently. He is able to follow commands. When another individual tries to enter the room, the physician asks the patient to “hold the door,” and he does so immediately. Based on his symptoms, which of the following labeled areas in the schematic overview of a normal brain is most likely affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An ischemic injury to area A, the premotor cortex, is associated with difficulty of planning, initiating, and maintaining muscle movements despite no presence of muscle weakness (apraxia) along with difficulties using sensory feedback for the control of movement. Hence, patients with premotor cortex lesions may be unable to execute motor movements needed to produce speech (verbal apraxia). Verbal apraxia is a disorder of speech articulation, characterized by halting speech and speech sound distortions and errors. This patient, however, has difficulty with language expression.

B) INCORRECT:

An ischemic injury to area B, the primary motor cortex, manifests with contralateral hemiplegia or hemiparesis as well as dysarthria due to a motor dysfunction of the facial muscles and tongue muscles. This results in typical pathologic speech patterns such as slurring, mumbling, and changes in speed and pitch. However, this patient has difficulty with language expression, not with the production of speech sounds.

C) INCORRECT:

An ischemic injury to area C, the primary somatosensory cortex, causes contralateral numbness, tingling, and partial sensory loss, which this patient does not have. Moreover, primary somatosensory cortex lesions would not affect speech production.

D) CORRECT:

This patient's nonfluent, telegraphic speech pattern with constant repetition of one word, in combination with preserved comprehension of simple sentences and commands, is characteristic of Broca aphasia (expressive aphasia). An ischemic stroke involving area D, the Broca area, in the dominant (usually left) hemisphere results in expressive aphasia. Affected individuals typically appear frustrated by their speech deficits. Language comprehension is relatively intact as long as the Wernicke area in the temporal lobe is unaffected, although there may be difficulties understanding grammatically complex speech. Broca aphasia due to cerebral infarction may occur as an isolated finding or can be accompanied by contralateral, brachiofacial sensorimotor hemiparesis.

Taking into account this patient's cardiovascular risk factors (hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus), his symptoms are likely the result of an acute ischemic stroke. This patient's tall stature could result from underlying homocystinuria, which predisposes to thromboses and atherosclerosis, and subsequent stroke. However, he lacks other features of homocystinuria, which include osteoporosis, lens dislocation, and a Marfanoid habitus with long, thin extremities.
Image Description:

The primary motor cortex, in the frontal lobe, is the origin of the fibers of the pyramidal tract.

The primary and secondary auditory cortices, where auditory input is processed, are located in the temporal lobe. The primary visual cortex is located at the occipital pole and is surrounded by the secondary visual cortex.

Different functions converge at association areas. The most well-known examples are the motor (Broca) and sensory (Wernicke) areas of speech, which are commonly located in the dominant hemisphere.

E) INCORRECT:

An ischemic injury to area E, the primary auditory cortex, can cause difficulty in sound localization and subtle hearing dysfunction if the injury is unilateral or it can cause cortical deafness with complete loss of comprehension if the injury is severe and bilateral. However, this patient's hearing is intact.

F) INCORRECT:

An ischemic injury to area F, the Wernicke area, causes Wernicke aphasia, which is characterized by markedly impaired comprehension, neologisms, long and grammatically correct but nonsensical sentences, and a lack of insight regarding the condition. This patient, however, expresses frustration at his speech impairment, showing insight and can understand simple sentences.

G) INCORRECT:

An ischemic injury to area G, the primary visual cortex, causes cortical blindness with macular sparing, not aphasia.
questions.hint: In response to further questioning, the patient says, “Hodor Hodor Hodor Hodor Hodor Hodor Hodor Hodor Hodor.”

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of episodic headaches associated with dizziness, nausea, and vomiting. Over-the-counter pain medications have failed to reduce her symptoms. An MRI of the brain shows isolated dilation of the left lateral ventricle. This dilatation is most likely caused by blockade of which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The arachnoid villi are responsible for resorption of cerebrospinal fluid, which then drains into the superior sagittal sinus. Impaired reabsorption may occur in the setting of CNS infections but would lead to communicating hydrocephalus, not isolated dilation of a lateral ventricle.

B) CORRECT:

The interventricular foramina (foramina of Monro) drain CSF from the lateral ventricles to the centrally located third ventricle. Thus, one-sided obstruction of either channel leads to dilation of the corresponding lateral ventricle and the associated mass symptoms in this patient. Unilateral ventriculomegaly may occur as a complication of CNS infection, neoplastic changes, or congenital defects, primarily during childhood. Idiopathic cases, on the other hand, have only rarely been described. Affected individuals may have signs of increased intracranial pressure, e.g., chronic headache.

The only available treatment options are neuroendoscopic septostomy or foraminoplasty, both of which can reduce symptoms. However, it appears that the reduction of ventricular size does not affect clinical outcome.
Image Description:

Within the brain, there are several interconnected CSF-filled spaces (ventricles). The largest of these are the lateral ventricles (first and second ventricles), which are located within the cerebral hemispheres. The third ventricle lies in the diencephalon, between the two thalamic hemispheres, and has several recesses. The fourth ventricle is located in the rhomboid fossa (dorsal to the pons/medulla oblongata). The lateral ventricles are connected to the third ventricle via the interventricular foramina. The third ventricle is connected to the fourth ventricle by the cerebral aqueduct. The fourth ventricle also connects the ventricular system to the subarachnoid space (which is also filled with CSF) via several openings (e.g., the median aperture).

C) INCORRECT:

The median aperture (foramen of Magendie) is the medial connection of the fourth ventricle and the cisterna magna, which allows for drainage of cerebrospinal fluid into the subarachnoid space. Obstruction does not necessarily lead to dilation of the ventricular system, as there are additional channels that allow CSF to drain to the subarachnoid space.

D) INCORRECT:

The lateral apertures (foramina of Luschka) connect the fourth ventricle to the cerebellomedullary cistern, allowing for drainage of the ventricular system into the subarachnoid space. Stenosis of either aperture does not necessarily result in dilation of the ventricles, as there are other channels that drain CSF into the subarachnoid space. True ventricle outlet obstruction is a rare condition in which all four ventricles are dilated even when only one aperture is obstructed. It may occur as a congenital variant in children, e.g., with Dandy-Walker malformation, or due to infection (i.e., arachnoiditis with subsequent membrane formation) in adults. However, isolated dilation of a lateral ventricle would not be expected.

E) INCORRECT:

The cerebral aqueduct (of Sylvius) drains cerebrospinal fluid from the third to the fourth ventricle. Thus, stenosis would lead to non-communicating hydrocephalus with dilation of the third and lateral ventricles rather than isolated dilation of a lateral ventricle.
Image Description:

Sagittal section of the brainstem reveals the three major components (from cranial to caudal: midbrain, pons, medulla oblongata) and their associated structures. The parts of the CSF space that traverse the brainstem are shown in blue.
questions.hint: The lateral ventricles are the two largest cavities of the ventricular system of the human brain and drain cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) into the central third ventricle.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man is brought to the physician because of a 2-week history of memory loss. Three weeks ago, he had a cardiac arrest that required cardiopulmonary resuscitation and intravenous epinephrine. On mental status examination, he cannot recall objects shown to him 20 minutes earlier but vividly recalls memories from before the incident. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following structures of the brain is most likely affected?

choices.text: Internal pyramidal layer of the amygdala
External pyramidal layer of the parietal cortex

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cerebellar Purkinje cells are very vulnerable to ischemic insults. However, patients with ischemic damage to this group of cells would present with intention tremor, nystagmus, and ataxia.

B) INCORRECT:

Microglial cells are relatively resistant to ischemic insults because they are not as metabolically active as neurons. In fact, these macrophages are typically seen in the inflammatory reaction to cellular injury after ischemia. Strokes affecting the dorsal midbrain present with Parinaud syndrome, not memory impairment.

C) INCORRECT:

The amygdala is a complex of nuclei located in the temporal lobe, it is not composed of cellular layers like the neocortex or hippocampus. Moreover, strokes affecting the amygdala typically result in uninhibited, aggressive behavior (Kluver-Bucy syndrome).

D) INCORRECT:

The external pyramidal layer of the parietal cortex is very vulnerable to ischemic injury. However, neuronal cell death in the dominant parietal cortex would lead to Gerstmann syndrome, not anterograde amnesia as seen here.

E) CORRECT:

Damage to the pyramidal cells of the hippocampus typically leads to anterograde amnesia, as seen in this patient. The hippocampus is the brain region most vulnerable to ischemic hypoxia, and only a few minutes of ischemia can lead to irreversible damage mediated by cytotoxic glutamatergic release and uptake. Other brain regions that are particularly susceptible to ischemic insults are neocortical pyramidal cells, striatal neurons, and Purkinje cells.

F) INCORRECT:

Astroglial cells (also known as astrocytes) of the putamen are relatively resistant to ischemic injury mainly because they can use glycogen stores for anaerobic metabolism. Moreover, injury to the cells of the putamen results in impaired voluntary muscle control rather than memory loss. Following an ischemic event, astrocytes become reactive and form a glial scar (reactive gliosis).
questions.hint: This patient presents with features of an ischemic stroke following a cardiac arrest. The short-term memory loss indicates selective neuronal necrosis of a structure within the limbic system.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man is brought to the physician by his mother because of concerns about his recent behavior. Three months ago, the patient first reported hearing loud voices coming from the ceiling of his room. During this time, he has also become increasingly worried that visitors to the house were placing secret surveillance cameras. Mental status examination shows tangential speech with paranoid thoughts. Treatment for this patient's condition predominantly targets which of the following dopaminergic pathways?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The positive symptoms of schizophrenia are thought to occur at least in part due to increased dopaminergic activity within the mesolimbic pathway. Antipsychotics are antagonists at the dopaminergic D2 receptors within this pathway and are the first-line treatment for this disorder. However, they show little benefit for the negative symptoms of schizophrenia, which are very difficult to treat.

B) INCORRECT:

The thalamocortical pathway is a glutamatergic pathway, not a dopaminergic pathway. It connects the thalamus to the cortex and is not significantly affected by antipsychotics.

C) INCORRECT:

Reduced dopaminergic activity in the mesocortical pathway (also known as the prefrontal cortical pathway) is thought to be involved in causing the negative symptoms of schizophrenia, such as reduced emotional expression and apathy, which this patient does not exhibit.

D) INCORRECT:

The corticostriatal pathway is a glutamatergic pathway, not a dopaminergic pathway. It connects the cortex to the basal ganglia and is involved in the control of movement. It is not significantly affected by antipsychotics.

E) INCORRECT:

The nigrostriatal pathway arises from the substantia nigra, and hypofunction of dopaminergic activity in this pathway is responsible for the motor symptoms of Parkinson disease. Extrapyramidal symptoms, including parkinsonism, are a common side effect of antipsychotic drugs as these inhibit dopaminergic activity in this pathway, but treatment for positive symptoms of schizophrenia does not target the nigrostriatal pathway.

F) INCORRECT:

Normal dopaminergic activity in the tuberoinfundibular pathway is responsible for the control of prolactin release from the anterior pituitary. Hyperprolactinemia is a common side effect of antipsychotic drugs due to inhibition of dopaminergic activity in this pathway, but treatment for positive symptoms of schizophrenia does not target the tuberoinfundibular pathway.
questions.hint: This patient shows several of the classic positive symptoms of schizophrenia (auditory hallucinations, disorganized speech, delusions). The first-line treatment for schizophrenia inhibits dopaminergic activity primarily within a brain pathway that is also important in mediating reward and addiction.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife because of the sudden onset of slurred speech and left-side weakness that began about an hour ago. His wife says the symptoms were preceded by a progressively worsening headache and visual disturbances. He has a history of alcohol use disorder and has smoked 2 packs of cigarettes daily for 20 years. His blood pressure is 210/92 mm Hg. He is only oriented to self and has difficulty answering questions. A CT scan of the head without contrast shows a large hyperdense fluid collection in the right putamen. Which of the following labeled structures most likely represents the affected location?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This structure is the head of the caudate nucleus, not the putamen. Lesions of the caudate nucleus have been implicated in the pathogenesis of Parkinson disease (depletion of dopaminergic neurons that synapse here), Huntington disease (atrophy of the caudate), and schizophrenia (reduced volume of the caudate).

B) INCORRECT:

This structure is the anterior limb of the internal capsule, not the putamen. Lesions of the internal capsule (e.g., due to a lacunar stroke from occlusion of the lenticulostriate artery) manifest with contralateral paralysis without cortical signs.

C) CORRECT:

This structure is the putamen. It forms the lentiform nucleus with the globus pallidus and the striatum with the caudate nucleus. The putamen has gabaminergic neurons that project onto the globus pallidus. It receives dopaminergic input from the substantia nigra pars compacta and glutaminergic input from the cortex. The putamen, which receives blood from the lenticulostriate arteries, is the most common location for hypertensive hemorrhage. This typically occurs due to rupture of Charcot-Bouchard microaneurysms. The putamen is also affected by degenerative conditions such as Huntington disease and Wilson disease.

The acute features of putaminal hemorrhage can vary widely and are usually attributed to the involvement of the surrounding structures. Patients with a small putaminal bleed may be asymptomatic or report features of a lacunar stroke syndrome (e.g., pure sensorimotor stroke). With large putaminal hemorrhage, patients can develop aphasia (dominant side) or hemineglect (non-dominant side), intraventricular hemorrhage, and raised intracranial tension.
Image Description:

Coronal section; frontal view

D) INCORRECT:

This structure is the claustrum, not the putamen. Lesions of the claustrum have been implicated in some cases of epilepsy.

E) INCORRECT:

This structure is the external capsule, not the putamen. Lesions of the external capsule are rare, with infarction being the most common lesion at this site (manifesting with cranial nerve palsies and dysarthria).

F) INCORRECT:

This structure is the globus pallidus, not the putamen. Dysfunction of the globus pallidus has been implicated in the pathogenesis of Huntington disease and Parkinson disease. Furthermore, bilateral lesions of the globus pallidus may be seen in carbon monoxide poisoning.
questions.hint: The putamen is the most lateral part of the basal ganglia.

questions.text: A 21-year-old man comes to his physician because he has been having problems during track practice. He has become increasingly clumsy, even falling during his race last week, and seems to be moving much slower than last year. During this period, his mother reports that he has also become more irritable and he is having trouble in his classes. He has no history of serious medical illness and takes no medications. He does not use illicit drugs or drink alcohol. Vital signs are within normal limits. He is alert and oriented but has a flat affect. His speech is slurred and monotonous. Examination shows rigidity and an unsteady, broad-based gait. Abdominal examination shows hepatosplenomegaly. An MRI of the brain shows cavitary degeneration of the putamen. Which of the following labeled structures corresponds to the lesions seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This structure is the caudate nucleus, which is part of the striatum. The striatum is affected in patients with Huntington disease (HD). HD can cause personality changes, movement abnormalities, and dysarthria. Also, in the case of genetic anticipation, HD can manifest in patients in their early twenties. However, the movement abnormality characteristic of early HD is chorea, which is not present in this patient. Moreover, there is no family history of HD to suggest anticipation. A different part of the striatum is affected in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

This structure is the internal capsule, a subcortical structure that contains motor and somatosensory projection fibers. A lesion affecting this site (e.g., an infarct) manifests with contralateral motor deficits. A different structure is affected in this patient.

C) CORRECT:

This structure is the putamen, which is typically affected early in the course of Wilson disease. In Wilson disease (hepatolenticular degeneration), damage to a component of the basal ganglia called the lentiform nucleus (putamen and globus pallidus) occurs as a result of copper accumulation. Damage to this area is the cause of this patient's parkinsonism, personality changes (irritability, flat affect), dysarthria, rigidity, and broad-based ataxic gait.
Image Description:

Transverse section; cranial view

D) INCORRECT:

This structure is the external globus pallidus, a component of the lentiform nucleus. While the external globus pallidus is often affected in Wilson disease, the structure that is affected in this patient is a different part of the lentiform nucleus.

E) INCORRECT:

This structure is the internal globus pallidus, a component of the lentiform nucleus. While the internal globus pallidus is often affected in Wilson disease, the structure that is affected in this patient is a different part of the lentiform nucleus.

F) INCORRECT:

The nuclei of the thalamus (structure F) are responsible for relaying and processing various types of sensory information; they are not involved in motor function. The thalamus is not commonly affected in Wilson disease.
questions.hint: The combination of parkinsonism, personality changes (irritability, flat affect), dysarthria, rigidity, broad-based ataxic gait, and hepatosplenomegaly in a young patient suggests Wilson disease. The putamen is located medial to the insular lobe.

questions.text: A 75-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her daughter for a 4-month history of increasing difficulty recognizing her friends and family. She has had to rely on recognizing haircuts, gait, and voices because she cannot remember their faces. Neurologic examination shows that she is able to recognize objects and name facial features such as the eyes and nose. On mental status examination, she is alert and has no deficits in cognition or short-term memory. An MRI of her head shows an inhomogenous 2-cm mass with perifocal edema in her brain. Which of the following brain regions is most likely affected?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A left posterior parietal cortex lesion in a right-handed patient would manifest with features of Gerstmann syndrome (e.g., agraphia without alexia, acalculia, finger agnosia, right-left disorientation). A similar lesion in a left-handed patient would manifest with constructional apraxia and/or spatial hemineglect. This patient presents with prosopagnosia, which is not a typical feature of parietal cortex lesions.

B) INCORRECT:

A right posterior superior temporal cortex lesion would manifest with left upper quadrantanopia, a visual field defect caused by damage to the Meyer loop. A lesion in this location can also cause aprosodia in right-handed patients and Wernicke aphasia in left-handed patients. This patient presents with prosopagnosia, which is not a feature of posterior superior temporal cortex lesions.
Image Description:

The primary motor cortex, in the frontal lobe, is the origin of the fibers of the pyramidal tract.

The primary and secondary auditory cortices, where auditory input is processed, are located in the temporal lobe. The primary visual cortex is located at the occipital pole and is surrounded by the secondary visual cortex.

Different functions converge at association areas. The most well-known examples are the motor (Broca) and sensory (Wernicke) areas of speech, which are commonly located in the dominant hemisphere.

C) INCORRECT:

Lesions in the hippocampus may cause anterograde amnesia, which can manifest with the inability to recognize faces of recently acquainted people. However, this patient has difficulty remembering familiar faces (friends and family), and she does not present with any other memory impairments.

D) INCORRECT:

The superior region of the parietal cortex contains the somatosensory association cortex and a section of the primary somatosensory cortex. A lesion in the right superior parietal cortex would manifest with left-sided astereognosis, apraxia, and possibly left-sided sensory deficits, none of which are seen here.
Image Description:

The primary motor cortex, in the frontal lobe, is the origin of the fibers of the pyramidal tract.

The primary and secondary auditory cortices, where auditory input is processed, are located in the temporal lobe. The primary visual cortex is located at the occipital pole and is surrounded by the secondary visual cortex.

Different functions converge at association areas. The most well-known examples are the motor (Broca) and sensory (Wernicke) areas of speech, which are commonly located in the dominant hemisphere.

E) CORRECT:

Prosopagnosia is caused by bilateral lesions or large unilateral (typically right-sided) lesions (e.g., brain tumors) in the ventral occipitotemporal cortex, which includes parts of the secondary visual cortex as well as parts of the temporal lobe. Individuals with prosopagnosia are able to visually perceive faces because the pathway to the primary visual cortex in the occipital lobe is still intact, but they have lost the ability to process the image properly. Affected individuals retain their ability to name parts of the face (e.g., nose, mouth) and are typically able to identify individuals by other cues (e.g., clothing, voice).
Image Description:

The 4 lobes of each cerebral hemisphere are separated by 3 main sulci:
–The central sulcus separates the frontal lobe from the parietal lobe.
–The lateral sulcus separates the temporal lobe from the frontal lobe and the parietal lobe.
–The parieto-occipital sulcus separates the parietal lobe from the occipital lobe.
questions.hint: This patient presents with prosopagnosia, which is characterized by an inability to recognize familiar faces. The brain region that is typically affected in this condition is supplied by the posterior cerebral artery.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by ambulance because of severe headache, nausea, and vomiting that began 2 hours ago. Two weeks ago, he was discharged from the hospital after being treated for bacterial meningitis. He appears disoriented. His pulse is 55/min, respirations are 10/min, and blood pressure is 155/90 mm Hg. Fundoscopy shows bilateral swelling of the optic discs. An MRI of the brain shows ventriculomegaly and scarring of a structure that is derived from the diencephalon. The patient’s symptoms are most likely to be caused by obstruction of which of the following parts of the ventricular system?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The central canal is present in the distal medulla oblongata and the entire length of the spinal cord. Obstruction of the central canal can, on rare occasion, occur following bacterial meningitis, but it would not cause the ventriculomegaly or elevated intracranial pressure seen here because CSF drains from a structure located cranial to the central canal. Instead, dilation of the central canal (syringomyelia) would develop and patients would present with features of a central cord syndrome. Furthermore, the central canal develops in the caudal part of the neural tube, not the diencephalon.

B) INCORRECT:

An obstruction in the cerebral aqueduct could cause ventriculomegaly and elevated intracranial pressure secondary to hydrocephalus, which are seen in this patient. This structure, however, is derived from the mesencephalon, not the diencephalon.
Image Description:

Within the brain, there are several interconnected CSF-filled spaces (ventricles). The largest of these are the lateral ventricles (first and second ventricles), which are located within the cerebral hemispheres. The third ventricle lies in the diencephalon, between the two thalamic hemispheres, and has several recesses. The fourth ventricle is located in the rhomboid fossa (dorsal to the pons/medulla oblongata). The lateral ventricles are connected to the third ventricle via the interventricular foramina. The third ventricle is connected to the fourth ventricle by the cerebral aqueduct. The fourth ventricle also connects the ventricular system to the subarachnoid space (which is also filled with CSF) via several openings (e.g., the median aperture).

C) INCORRECT:

Obstruction of one or both of the lateral apertures is unlikely to result in ventriculomegaly or elevated intracranial pressure, as seen here, because CSF can still drain out of the ventricular system into the subarachnoid space via the foramen of Magendie. Moreover, the lateral apertures are a part of the ventricular system that is derived from the metencephalon and myelencephalon, not the diencephalon.

D) INCORRECT:

An obstruction in the outflow tract of one or both of the lateral ventricles could cause ventriculomegaly (of the affected lateral ventricle) and elevated intracranial pressure, which are seen here. However, the lateral ventricles develop from the telencephalon, not the diencephalon.

E) CORRECT:

The only part of the ventricular system that is derived from the diencephalon is the third ventricle. The diencephalon is one of the five secondary brain vesicles, the other four being the telencephalon, mesencephalon, metencephalon, and myelencephalon, each of which gives rise to distinct structures of the mature brain. The lateral ventricles arise from the telencephalon, the cerebral aqueduct arises from the mesencephalon, and the fourth ventricle arises from the metencephalon and myelencephalon. The diencephalon and telencephalon are derived from the forebrain (prosencephalon), whereas the metencephalon and myelencephalon develop from the hindbrain (rhombencephalon).
Image Description:

The illustration depicts the regions of the mature brain (names in parentheses) and their embryological derivation from the 3 primary vesicles (prosencephalon, mesencephalon, rhombencephalon) and 5 subdivisions (telencephalon, diencephalon, mesencephalon, metencephalon, myelencephalon). Note that this nomenclature is not always consistent, as some sources also refer to the regions of the mature brain using the embryological terminology (e.g., “prosencephalon” instead of “forebrain,” etc).

Note also that while the posterior pituitary (neurohypophysis) is a downgrowth of the diencephalon (and therefore shown in orange), the anterior pituitary (adenohypophysis) is separately derived as an upgrowth of the oral ectoderm (therefore shown in white).

F) INCORRECT:

An obstruction in the fourth ventricle could cause ventriculomegaly and elevated intracranial pressure secondary to hydrocephalus, which are seen in this patient. However, the fourth ventricle is not derived from the diencephalon. The upper part of the fourth ventricle develops from the metencephalon, while the lower part develops from the myelencephalon.
questions.hint: Clinical features of increased intracranial pressure (e.g., headache, nausea, vomiting, papilledema, bradycardia, hypertension) with ventriculomegaly and scarring in a structure derived from the diencephalon indicate noncommunicating hydrocephalus, which can occur as a late complication of bacterial meningitis. The thalamus, hypothalamus, subthalamic nuclei, and pineal gland, which also arise from the diencephalon, form the boundaries of this part of the ventricular system.

questions.text: A 66-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after his wife found him lying on his back on the ground, next to a ladder that was leaning against the side of their garage. She reports that he was conscious when she found him, but seemed confused and reported a headache. He has hypertension and atrial fibrillation. His medications are metoprolol and rivaroxaban. On admission, he appears somnolent and is oriented only to person. His pulse is 68/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 135/75 mm Hg. There is a large hematoma with swelling on the occiput. Supportive treatment is initiated. A noncontrast CT scan of the head shows a 3-cm intraparenchymal hyperdense lesion with a surrounding hypodense area in the orbitofrontal lobe. Which of the following sequela is most likely to develop in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Contralateral paralysis can result from damage to the primary motor cortex, which is located in the precentral gyrus of the frontal lobe. This patient's CT scan findings are consistent with injury of the orbitofrontal lobe, which is located anterior to the precentral gyrus. Motor deficits are not expected in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Impaired language comprehension can develop in patients with lesions of the Wernicke area, which is located in the posterior part of the superior portion of the temporal lobe. Injury of the orbitofrontal lobe is not associated with impaired language comprehension.

C) CORRECT:

The prefrontal cortex is responsible for higher cognitive functions such as goal setting, decision making, concentration, short-term memory storage, and personality development. Therefore, injury (e.g., cerebral contusion, hemorrhage, ischemia) to the frontal lobe(s) can result in personality changes, loss of inhibition and impulse control, emotional lability, impaired judgment, and/or inappropriate social interactions.

Cerebral contusions are associated with severe intracranial complications and therefore require close observation for at least 24 hours. Given the size of this patient's contusion (> 1 cm) and the presence of confusion, he will most likely require inpatient observation and further neurological evaluation. In patients with worsening symptoms (e.g., progressive neurologic deterioration, increased intracranial pressure, hemorrhage volume > 20 cm3), decompressive craniotomy may be considered.
Image Description:

CT head (axial section; without IV contrast)

Brain window (left): A contusion is visible within the left frontal lobe as a well-defined heterogeneous lesion (green overlay) surrounded by edema (hypodense rim; white overlay).

Bone window (right): A fracture of the skull in the occipital region (red overlay) can be seen.

These features are characteristic of a coup-contrecoup injury wherein the impact of the external force to the back of the head resulted in a cerebral contusion in the frontal lobe.

D) INCORRECT:

Long-term memory deficits can develop in patients with repeated traumatic brain injury (e.g., professional contact sports athletes) or as a result of a single event of trauma to the hippocampus (which is located in the temporal lobe). This patient has no history of repeated traumatic brain injury. Orbitofrontal lobe injury is not associated with long-term memory deficits.

E) INCORRECT:

Contralateral sensory deficits can develop as a result of a pure sensory stroke or a sensorimotor stroke, both of which affect regions of the somatosensory area (e.g., thalamus, posterior limb of the internal capsule, postcentral gyrus of the parietal lobe). Injury of the orbitofrontal lobe is not associated with contralateral sensory deficits.
questions.hint: Although the point of impact is occipital in this patient, he has developed a significant contrecoup hemorrhage in his prefrontal cortex, likely worsened by anticoagulation therapy.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man is brought to the emergency department two hours after the sudden onset of speech difficulty. On examination, he is alert and able to follow commands. He understands spoken and written language, but has difficulty forming words. His speech is nonfluent, slow, and effortful. He attempts to speak but produces short phrases with poor grammar. Naming and repetition are impaired. Damage to which of the following structures best explains this patient’s clinical findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF) is a paired brainstem tract that interconnects the abducens, oculomotor, and trochlear nuclei to coordinate conjugate horizontal eye movements. The MLF does not have a role in speech production. Lesions of the MLF produce internuclear ophthalmoplegia (impaired adduction of the ipsilateral eye and nystagmus of the contralateral abducting eye).

B) CORRECT:

Damage to the posterior part of the inferior frontal gyrus in the dominant hemisphere (Broca area) impairs the brain’s ability to coordinate the complex motor functions required for speech production, resulting in a nonfluent, slow, and effortful speech with short, poorly constructed phrases and impaired repetition. Since this region is not the primary center for language comprehension, patients are typically still able to understand both spoken and written language. These features are characteristic of Broca aphasia, i.e., expressive aphasia (see “Types of aphasia” table).

Key learning point: A lesion in Broca area (inferior frontal gyrus) causes expressive aphasia.
Image Description:

The primary motor cortex, in the frontal lobe, is the origin of the fibers of the pyramidal tract.

The primary and secondary auditory cortices, where auditory input is processed, are located in the temporal lobe. The primary visual cortex is located at the occipital pole and is surrounded by the secondary visual cortex.

Different functions converge at association areas. The most well-known examples are the motor (Broca) and sensory (Wernicke) areas of speech, which are commonly located in the dominant hemisphere.

C) INCORRECT:

Lesions of the superior temporal gyrus in the dominant hemisphere cause Wernicke aphasia (receptive aphasia), resulting in fluent but nonsensical speech with poor comprehension and impaired repetition. This patient has preserved understanding but has slow, effortful speech, making a lesion in the superior temporal gyrus unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

Lesions in the arcuate fasciculus disrupt the connection between language comprehension and production, typically resulting in conduction aphasia. Although conduction aphasia can manifest with impaired repetition, both comprehension and fluency are mostly intact, making a lesion in the arcuate fasciculus unlikely.

E) INCORRECT:

The angular gyrus, located in the parietal lobe, is involved in processes such as reading and writing. Lesions in this area are associated with agraphia, alexia, and sometimes Gerstmann syndrome. This patient presents with nonfluent speech, making a lesion in a different structure more likely.
questions.hint: Patients with this type of aphasia are typically aware of their language deficits, which often leads to frustration during communication attempts.
